turns.speaker: STIEGLER
turns.text: Mr. Gardiner, I'm Ronald Stiegler, of Harvard Books.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hello, Ronald.

turns.speaker: STIEGLER
turns.text: Mr. Gardiner, my editors and I have been wondering if you'd consider writing a book for us? Something on your political philosophy. What do you say?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I can't write.

turns.speaker: STIEGLER
turns.text: Of course, who can nowadays? I have trouble writing a post card to my children! Look, we could give you a six figure advance, provide you with the very best ghostwriter, research assistants, proof readers...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I can't read.

turns.speaker: STIEGLER
turns.text: Of course not! No one has the time to read! One glances at things, watches television...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I like to watch.

turns.speaker: STIEGLER
turns.text: Sure you do! No one reads!... Listen, book publishing isn't exactly a bed of roses these days...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: What sort of bed is it?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: May I help you, Mr. Gardiner?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I would like to go to Rand Memorial Hospital.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: ... Sir?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: ... Did you wish to see someone, sir?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I would like to see Ben.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Rand, of course. Right this way, sir.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Mr. Chance, I'm very pleased to meet you.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: ... Then you really are a gardener?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Your appearance doesn't suggest that at all, Mr. Chance.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Oh. Thank you.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: What about money?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I never needed money.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Some pictures...?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. Of men and women.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: How about taxes, Mr. Chance, surely you must have paid taxes?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Might you have a birth certificate, Mr. Chance?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No.  That's where Joe fixed the bricks.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I am allowed to go to the attic and select any of the Old Man's suits. They all fit me very well. I can also take his shirts, shoes and coats.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: It is quite amazing how those clothes have come back into style.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I have seen styles on television.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Good day, Mr. Chance.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Good day, Sally.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: This is terrible, sir -  I hope you're not badly injured...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No. I'm not badly injured. But my leg is very sore.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Can you walk? It's not broken, is it?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: It's very sore.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: I don't think we should call anyone just yet, it may not even be all that serious.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I agree.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Let's have a look, do you mind?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Of course. I would like to look.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: It's starting to swell, is it painful?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Please, sir.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I've never ridden in an automobile.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: I assure you, sir, David is a very careful driver. Please, won't you let us take you?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... Yes. You can take me.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Very good.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... My suitcase.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Yes sir. I'll take care of that.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Does it have a television?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: No - but Mr. Rand does have one with an electric motor, that way he can get around by himself.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: How long do we stay in here?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: How long? I don't know, see what the doctor says ...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... That is a very small room.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yes sir, I guess that's true smallest room in the house.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. It seems to be.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... Hmmm... Elevator.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: ... Yes sir - elevator!

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: ... Evening, Chance.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... Good evening, Louise.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: ... The Old Man is getting weaker, Chance.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: I'm afraid he's slippin' a bit with every hour that goes by...

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: ... Back up those stairs - damn... That Man's needin' me more and more just before he never needs me again...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Is his back feeling better?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Good morning, Louise.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: He's dead, Chance! The Old Man's dead!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... I see.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: Must of happened durin' the night, I don't know... Lord, he wasn't breathin' and as cold as a fish. I touched him, just to see, and you believe me, Chance - that's doin' more than I get paid to do... Then I just covered him up, pulled the sheet over his head...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I've seen that done.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: Then I got the hell out of that room and called the doctor and I think I woke him probably, he wasn't any too alert. He just said, 'Yeah, he's been expectin' it and said he'd send somebody over...' Lord, what a mornin'!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... Yes, Louise, it's snowing in the garden today. Have you looked outside and seen the snow? It's very white.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: Dammit, Boy! Is that all you got to say? More gobbledegook?  That Old Man's layin' up there dead as hell and it just don't make any difference to you!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Louise. I have seen it often. It happens to old people.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: Well, ain't that the truth...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. It is.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: Oh, Lord, Chance - I don't know what I was expectin' from you... I'm sorry for yellin' like I did... No sir, I just don't know what I was expectin' ...  ... I 'spose I'd better gather up some breakfast for you...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I'm very hungry.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: Well, no more stewin' those prunes every mornin', that's somethin', I guess...  ... what are you goin' to do now, Chance?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I'm going to work in the garden.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: ... Well, ain't you the gentleman this mornin'...  ... gotta go now, Chance...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LOUISE
turns.text: You're gonna need somebody, someone's gotta be around for you, boy...  ... You oughta find yourself a lady, Chance...  But I guess it oughta be an old lady, 'cause you ain't gonna do a young one any good, not with that little thing of yours...  ... You're always gonna be a little boy, ain't you?  ... Goodbye, Chance...

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Mr. Gardiner, how very nice to have you with us this evening.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: I'd like to thank you for filling in on such short notice for the Vice President.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: You're welcome.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: I always find it surprising, Mr. Gardiner, to find men like yourself, who are working so intimately with the President, yet manage to remain relatively unknown.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. That is surprising.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: ... Well, your anonymity will be a thing of the past from now on.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I hope so.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Yes... Of course, you know, Mr. Gardiner, that I always prefer an open and frank conversation with my guests, I hope you don't object to that.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No. I don't object.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Fine, then let's get started. The current state of our country is of vital interest to us all, and I would like to know if you agree with the President's view of the economy?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Which view?

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Come now, Mr. Gardiner, before his speech at the Financial Institute the President consulted with you and Benjamin Rand, did he not?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I was there with Ben.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: I know that, Mr. Gardiner.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Well, let me rephrase the question; the President compared the economy of this country to a garden, and stated that after a period of decline a time of growth would naturally follow. Do you go along with this belief?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I know the garden very well. I have worked in it all my life. It is a good garden and a healthy one; its trees are healthy and so are its shrubs and flowers, as long as they are trimmed and watered in the right seasons. The garden needs a lot of care. I do agree with the President; everything in it will grow strong, and there is plenty of room in it for new trees and new flowers of all kinds.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Don't we need a leader capable of guiding us through the seasons? The bad as well as the good?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. We need a very good gardener.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Well, Mr. Gardiner, from the sound of our audience, I'd say that your words are a most welcome respite from what we've been hearing from others...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: I'm sorry to say that our time is running short, but before we close, I'd like to ask one final question. What sort of gardener, sir, would you be?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I am a very serious gardener.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hello, Thomas... I'm Chance, the gardener.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... The gardener?  ... Yes, of course... Mr. Chance, this is Ms. Hayes.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... We're with Franklin, Jennings and Roberts, the law firm handling the estate.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Thomas - I understand.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... Are you waiting for someone? An appointment?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I'm waiting for my lunch.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Your lunch? You have a luncheon appointment here?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. Louise will bring me lunch.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Louise?... The maid?...  But she should have left earlier today...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I see...

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... You've quite a sense of humor, Mr. Chance - but all kidding aside, may I ask just what you are doing here?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I live here.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: You live here?  ... We don't have any record of that.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. It's very cold outside today, isn't it, Thomas?

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... How long have you been living here?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Ever since I can remember, since I was a child.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Since you were a child?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Thomas. I have always been here. I have always worked in the garden.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Do you have any proof of your employment, Mr. Chance - any checks from the deceased, any contracts or documents?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: How were you compensated for these duties you say you performed?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Compensated...?

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: How were you paid?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I was given meals, and a home...

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Mr. Chance, perhaps you could show us some identification with your address -- a Driver's License, a credit card, checkbook?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, I do not have any of those.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Then how about medical records? Could you give us the name of your doctor, or your dentist?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I have no need for a doctor or dentist. I have never been ill. I have never been allowed outside of this house, and, except for Joe, I have never had any visitors.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... Joe? Who's Joe?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Joe Saracini. He was a mason that did some repairs on the brickwork at the rear of the house. That was in 1952.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I remember when he came. He was very fat and had short hair and showed me some pictures from a funny little book.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Mr. Chance, that was twenty-seven years ago.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes and the Old Man used to come to my garden. He would read and rest there.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Come now, Mr. Jennings had been bedridden for thirty-five years, since he fractured his spine.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Thomas, that is correct. Then he stopped visiting my garden.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... We shall need some proof of your having resided here, Mr. Chance.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: You have me, I am here. What more proof do you need?

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Have you served in the Army?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, Thomas. But I have seen the Army on television.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Those trees were very young when I first arrived.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Are you related to the deceased, Mr. Chance?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, I don't think so. And I have planted and shaped all the hedges, and in the springtime you will be able to see my flowers.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... Do you drive this, Mr. Chance?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, Thomas. I have never been in an automobile.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: The Old Man gave me nice television sets, this one has remote control.  He has one just like it.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Mr. Chance, the fact remains that we have no information of your having any connection with the deceased.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I understand.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: What are your plans now, Mr. Chance?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I would like to stay and work in my garden.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Mr. Chance, assuming what you say is the truth, I would like to know what sort of claim you are planning to make against the deceased's estate.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I'm fine, Thomas. The garden is a healthy one. There is no need for a claim.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Good. That's good. Then if you would please sign a paper to that effect.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, Thomas. I don't know how to sign.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Come now, Mr. Chance.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I have no claim, Thomas.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: But you won't sign, correct?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Correct.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Very well, Mr. Chance - if you insist on dragging this matter on... But I must inform you this house will be closed tomorrow at noon. If indeed, you do reside here, you will have to move out.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Move out? I don't understand, Thomas.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: I think you do, Mr. Chance. However, I will reiterate, this house is closed and you must leave...  Call me if you change your mind about signing.  C'mon, Sally - let's grab a bite...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. President.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: ... Hello.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: You look much taller on television, Mr. President.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: ... Oh, really...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Well, Mr. Gardiner, that's just fine with me - I'm a man that appreciates a frank discussion... Be seated, please, Mr. Gardiner...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I will.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Now, Ben, did you happen to get a chance to...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Do you agree with Ben, Mr. Gardiner? Are we finished? Or do you think we can stimulate growth through temporary incentives?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: As long as the roots are not severed, all is well and all will be well in the garden.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: ... In the garden?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: That is correct. In a garden, growth has its season. There is spring and summer, but there is also fall and winter. And then spring and summer again...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: ... Spring and summer...  Yes, I see... Fall and winter.  Yes, indeed...  Could you go through that one more time, please, Mr. Gardiner?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. It has.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: ... You will honor me and my family with a visit, won't you?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I will.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Wonderful, we'll all look forward to seeing you.  Is Eve around? I'd like to say hello.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: ... Gardiner is laconic, matter-of fact. The scuttlebutt is that he's a strong candidate for one of the vacant seats on the board of First American. But before we can do any sort of a piece on the man, we're going to need facts on his background...  ... Kinney, what did you come up with?

turns.speaker: KINNEY
turns.text: ... Nothing.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: ... Skip the levity, Kinney - what have you got?

turns.speaker: KINNEY
turns.text: ... I realize this sounds banal but there is no information of any sort on Gardiner. We have no material on him - zilch...

turns.speaker: KINNEY
turns.text: ... Sid, be reasonable - I've been everywhere, there's no place left to check!

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Try again.

turns.speaker: KINNEY
turns.text: Sure, try again - where? There's nothing, it's like he never existed!

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Try again.

turns.speaker: KINNEY
turns.text: Sid, it's useless!

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: I said - try again.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, Ben - I miss you so when I'm out... How are you feeling?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Tired... And I'm getting tired of being so tired. Other than that, I'm doing very well.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: No headaches?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: No, it's been a good day - better than yours, from what I've been told.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You heard?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I may be a shut-in, but I do not lack for news. I'm sorry you had to go through all that.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, it wasn't all that bad, darling. We were fortunate that Mr. Gardiner turned out to be so reasonable.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Reasonable? Good, I'd like to meet a reasonable man. Why don't you ask this Gardiner to join us for dinner?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Do you feel well enough for that?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Hah!... Tell me the truth, Eve - if I wait until I feel better, will I ever meet the man?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh. I'm very sorry. Well, if you have any need for any of our facilities, please do not hesitate to ask.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Do you need a secretary?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I'm becoming quite attached to Chauncey - quite attached...  ... And so are you, aren't you, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Yes, I am, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: That's good... That's good.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Ben, really...

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... Thank you, Chauncey... Thank you very much.  ... All right, Robert, I'm all yours.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Good evening, Mrs. Rand.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Good evening, Wilson.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I shall take the gentleman to the third floor guest suite, ma'am. Dr. Allenby is standing by.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Thank you, Wilson. That will be fine.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Thank you, Greta.  I'll be with Mr. Rand if I'm needed.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'll see you after the doctor has a look at your leg, Mr. Gardiner.

turns.speaker: SOPHIE
turns.text: Eve, child! How nice of you to come.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Hello, Sophie.

turns.speaker: SOPHIE
turns.text: And look who you brought with!

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Sophie, this is Chauncey Gardiner...

turns.speaker: SOPHIE
turns.text: Oh, I've been just dying to meet you, Mr. Gardiner!

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey, this is Mrs. Sophia Rowley.

turns.speaker: SOPHIE
turns.text: Come on, Eve. Let's let the men talk, there are so many people that have been asking about you.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Would you two excuse me for a moment?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: ... How are the kids getting along?

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: Oh. Well, I just talked to Cindy this morning. She loves California, but to quote her, she says, 'The Secret Service is getting to be a drag.' I guess she wants her privacy...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Huh... I'm glad they're along with her, if you know what I mean... How about Jack?

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: Well, I think Jack needs some time alone with you, darling... He's getting to that age, you know... He really misses you...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Yeah... I'll have a talk with him as soon as...

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: ... Maybe you should talk to somebody, darling.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: No, that won't do any good.

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: ... Is it me? Is there something I've done?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Oh, no, sweetheart - it's not you...

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: It's your damn job. It never happened when you were a senator...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: It's not that, I just...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: I can certainly understand that...

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: Of course... I'm so sorry for you, Eve...

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: ... This is another world, Tom - I never would have believed it...

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Yeah... He and my father used to ride together back in the thirties... Fox hunting... Before I was born...

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: ... Would you take me on a tour?

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Gladly...  ... The safe is in Mr. Jennings' bedroom, that'll be stop number one.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... What do you make of all this?

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: I really don't know, Tom - he seems so honest and simple... In a way, he's quite charming...

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... Yeah...

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: ... It's very bizarre - I don't know what to think...

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Well... He's either very, very bright or very, very dense - he's hard to figure...  ... Let's just keep everything legal.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: It's that gardener!

turns.speaker: JOHANNA
turns.text: Yes, Chauncey Gardiner.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: No! He's a real gardener!

turns.speaker: JOHANNA
turns.text: He does talk like one, but I think he's brilliant.

turns.speaker: JOHANNA
turns.text: ... Business, bullshit! Going out in the middle of the night to meet that bitch in a bar...

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Sally Hayes is not a bitch - she's a damn fine attorney! I've got to talk to her about this Gardiner...

turns.speaker: JOHANNA
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Look, Johanna...

turns.speaker: JOHANNA
turns.text: I said good night!

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Yes? What have you found?

turns.speaker: KARPATOV
turns.text: We have nothing on him, Ambassador Skrapinov.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Quietly, please. Mr. Gardiner, for one, understands our language.

turns.speaker: KARPATOV
turns.text: Sorry, Comrade Ambassador.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: What do you mean there is nothing? That's impossible.

turns.speaker: KARPATOV
turns.text: There is no information available on the man before he moved into Benjamin Rand's. It has proven to be such a difficult task that it has resulted in the loss of one of our agents to the United States Government.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: But... Where was this man Gardiner before last week?

turns.speaker: KARPATOV
turns.text: Apparently the White House shares our curiosity - they have also launched an investigation, and, according to our sources, neither the F.B.I. nor the C.I.A. has met with success.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: I see. Clearly, such interest on their part is of great political significance.

turns.speaker: KARPATOV
turns.text: Clearly, yes comrade.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Hmmm... Take this down.  I want this quote included in the Tass coverage; 'Chauncey Gardiner, in an intimate discussion with Ambassador Skrapinov, noted that "Unless the leaders of the opposing political systems move the chairs on which they sit closer to each other, all of their seats will be pulled from under them by rapid social and political changes."'

turns.speaker: KARPATOV
turns.text: Very good, Your Excellency.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Kaufman, I'm going to need information on Mr. Chauncey Gardiner's background.

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Gardiner, yes, sir.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: And put it through on a Code Red - I want it as soon as possible.

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: No problem, Chief.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: ... Gentlemen, I quoted this man on national television today he is obviously a financial sophisticate of some reknown.

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Yes, sir - we are aware of all that, but still, we haven't been able to...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: He's an advisor and close personal friend of Rand's! For Christ sakes, they have volumes of data on Benjamin!

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Yes, Mr. President, we attempted to contact Mr. Rand, but he was too ill to...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: I do not want Benjamin Rand disturbed! You have other ways of gathering information than to trouble a dying man. Use whatever agencies are necessary to put together a detailed history of Chauncey Gardiner, if you run into problems, alert Honeycutt.  I'll be in the office at seven in the morning and I would like to have it at that time.  I've got to take a leak.

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Right, Chief.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: This is not what I requested.

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: This information goes back three days. I want the standard file, you know that.

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Right, Chief.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: So...? Where the hell is it?

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: We... uh, have been unable to come up with any information before the man appeared at Mr. Rand's home ... and, uh...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: What the hell are you talking about, Kaufman?

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Well, we do have data from Honeycutt's sources, Chief - but it isn't pertinent.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: I'd like to hear that data, Kaufman.

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: ... So what does all that add up to?

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Well, sir - it occurred to us that he might be an agent of a foreign power. But, we ruled that out, as they invariably are provided with too much documentation, too much American identity... We, uh...don't quite know what to make of it yet, sir... But we'll keep on top of it, Mr. President - we'll come up with the answer.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: I would appreciate that.

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Sorry to disturb you, chief but we have new developments.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Oh? What?

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: We have word that the Soviets have put out a top priority alert for information on Gardiner's background. So far, they haven't come up with a thing - what's more, as a result of their eagerness, one of their ablest agents blew his cover, we have him in custody at this time.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Good. Anything else?

turns.speaker: KAUFMAN
turns.text: Yes, chief - eight other foreign powers have put Gardiner under surveillance. We're around-the clock now, sir - I'll keep you posted.

turns.speaker: NOVOGROD
turns.text: The rank-and-file in the FBI feel he is FBI, but others feel he is a CIA man who knows how to destroy FBI files.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: That could be possible...

turns.speaker: NOVOGROD
turns.text: But we are quite certain, comrade, that this man Gardiner is a leading member of an American elitist faction planning a coup d'etat.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: A coup d'etat! Of course, that was foreseen by Lenin himself!

turns.speaker: NOVOGROD
turns.text: That is correct, Comrade Skrapinov. We have ascertained that Gardiner heads a big-business power group that will soon be taking over the American government.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Big business. I could work with that faction quite nicely, Colonel Novogrod.

turns.speaker: NOVOGROD
turns.text: You have proven that already, Comrade Skrapinov, you are to be congratulated for recognizing the importance of this man and establishing an early friendship.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Thank you, Colonel.

turns.speaker: NOVOGROD
turns.text: Let us toast to the success of the coup.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Ben!

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... Mr. President, how good to see you.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: It's so good to see you too, Ben, you look terrific!

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I'm not convinced of that, Mr. President, but your visit has raised my spirits...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Well, I'm delighted to be here, my friend. I've missed you.  Here, sit down, get off your feet.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Mr. President, I'd like you to meet my dear friend, Mr. Chauncey Gardiner.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Mr. Gardiner, my pleasure.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: I just wondered if you had gone over my speech, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Yes, I did.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: ... Well?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Overall - pretty good. But, Mr. President, I think it's very dangerous to resort to temporary measures at this stage of the game.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Well, Ben... I...

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I sympathize with your position, Mr. President, I know how difficult it is to be straightforward, the reaction to such a speech could be chaos.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: That's too big a risk, I can't take the chance.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... There is no longer any margin for inflation, it has gone as far as it can, you've reached your limits on taxation, dependence on foreign energy has reached a crisis, and, from where I see it, Mr. President, the Free Enterprise System has reached the breaking point. We are on the brink of another crash from which recovery might not be possible.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: It's that serious, huh?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I'm afraid so.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: No, she flew up to Boston for another charity event. She'll be sorry to have missed you.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: I'm sorry, too. Well, Nancy wanted me to send along her best to the two of you - and, Ben, I want to thank you for your time and thoughts.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Nonsense, Mr. President - I thank you for coming to spend time with a dying man.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Now, Ben, I won't have any of that. Why don't you listen to your good friend Chauncey this is a time to think of life!

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: You're right, Mr. President I don't like feeling sorry for myself.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Take care of yourself, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: You take care too, Bobby.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Mr. Gardiner...

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: John! Great to see you! Sorry about the cunt at reception.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: This is my fiancee Maxine.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: I'll get right to the point, Larry. I'm a puppet now...

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: I'm being controlled by the world's greatest puppeteer, Craig Schwartz...

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Oh yeah, he's good.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: ... and I want to show off his skills by performing a one-puppet extravaganza in Reno.

turns.speaker: CABBIE
turns.text: Say, aren't you that actor guy?

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CABBIE
turns.text: John Makel...

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Malkovich.

turns.speaker: CABBIE
turns.text: Malkovich!

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: CABBIE
turns.text: The one where you're that jewel thief.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: I never played a jewel thief.

turns.speaker: CABBIE
turns.text: Who am I thinking of?

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: CABBIE
turns.text: I'm pretty sure it was you. Hey, could I get your autograph now? It's for .... oh, what the hell, it's for me! I'm your biggest fan!

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Yeah, okay.

turns.speaker: ERROLL
turns.text: Hello, I'm here about the ad.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Please, have a seat.

turns.speaker: ERROLL
turns.text: When you say, I can be somebody else, what do you mean exactly?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Exactly that. We can put you inside someone else's body for fifteen minutes.

turns.speaker: ERROLL
turns.text: Oh, this is just the medical breakthrough I've been waiting for. Are their any side effects? Please say no! Please say no!

turns.speaker: ERROLL
turns.text: Oh, thank you! Thank you! Thousand times, thank you!

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Tell your friends.

turns.speaker: ERROLL
turns.text: Oh, I will, and I have many, many friends and associates, my friend. All, by the way, in Overeaters Anonymous. All of them fat and alone like me, all of them dream of being someone else, all of them with John Malkovich as their second choice!

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Morning.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Gotta run. Shipment of grub worms coming in first thing.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Enjoy.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Craig, listen, honey, I've been thinking... maybe you'd feel better if you got, you know, a job or something.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: We've been over this. Nobody's looking for a puppeteer in today's wintry economic climate.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Well, you know, maybe something else until this whole puppet thing turns around.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: The Great Mantini doesn't need a day job.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Craig, everyone can't be Derek Mantini.  Well, grub worms are waiting. Do me a favor?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Would you check in on Elijah? He seems to be a little under the weather this morning.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Which one is Elijah again?

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: The monkey.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yeah. Okay.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Is the trial date set?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: May 11th.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Why'd you do it, Craig?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I'm a puppeteer.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Why, Craig. why?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I... puppeteer.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Isn't that cute? I just taught her that.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Adorable. What time are they supposed to be here?

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Seven-ish

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: We have to make it an early night.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: They'll understand. Besides I've got a morning appointment tomorrow with Elijah's shrink. We're getting to the bottom of this acid stomach.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Hmmm.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Some sort of childhood trauma, she thinks. Possible feelings of inadequacy as a chimp. Interesting, huh?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Hmmm.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yeah, just an idea I had.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: She's very beautiful.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Just an idea I had.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Sorry, I'm so late. Lester just wouldn't let me go. Were supposed to have dinner with him on Friday. I can get us out of it if you want. He's really amazing, this insane old lech. It's actually sort of amusing when you get past just how disgusting it is.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Did you eat?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Nah. I'm not hungry. I'm sorry I didn't call. It was just, you know, hard to get away.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: I was worried.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I'm sorry. How was your evening?

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Tom-Tom's puncture wound is infected.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: The ferret?

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: The iguana.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: I dressed the wound. Then I've just been feeding everyone, putting everyone to bed.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yeah. You want a beer?

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: No thanks. I'm going to turn in.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: All right. I'll be in my workshop for a little while. I'll be in in a little while. I need to unwind a little.  I'll be in soon. A little while.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: 'kay.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous. There is no such thing as a portal into someone else's brain.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Brain. soul, I'm telling you, Lotte. I was right inside him looking out. We're going to be rich.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: I want to try.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: I want to be John Malkovich. Tomorrow morning. Plus I'd like to meet this partner of yours.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Well, you know we're going to be very busy tomorrow. I'll tell you what. Let's do it tonight. Right now.

turns.speaker: LOTTE
turns.text: Now?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yeah. We'll do it right now. On the way to Lester's house.
